paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper reports two KCNH2 mutations associated with congenital long QT syndrome in two pediatric patients, detailing their clinical presentations and genetic findings.

patients.phenotype: Congenital long QT syndrome, Torsades de Pointes

individual_records.phenotype_details: Prolonged QT interval, syncope, Torsades de Pointes
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Case one, a 6-year-old boy, had first syncope during physical training at age 5.

functional_data.summary: The mutation is a missense variant that may disrupt protein structure and function.
assays: Protein stability prediction using SIFT and MutPred

variants.additional_notes: The mutation was confirmed via Sanger sequencing.
key_quotes: KCNH2 heterozygous variant p.Ala614Val may disrupt its protein structure and ability.

patients.phenotype: Congenital long QT syndrome, Torsades de Pointes

individual_records.phenotype_details: Prolonged QT interval, syncope, Torsades de Pointes
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Case two, a 13-year-old girl, experienced serial syncope attacks at age 11 and was diagnosed as epilepsy.

functional_data.summary: The mutation is a missense variant that may disrupt protein structure and function.
assays: Protein stability prediction using SIFT and MutPred

variants.additional_notes: The mutation was confirmed via Sanger sequencing.
key_quotes: KCNH2 heterozygous variants (p.Thr613Met) may disrupt its protein structure and ability.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
